awd_titl_txt: Characterization and Biosynthesis of Non-Methanotrophic Methanobactins
awd_abstract_narration:
Dayna Patterson is awarded a FY21 Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research (NSF MPS-Ascend) Fellowship from the Chemistry Division, to conduct a program of research and activities related to broadening participation by groups underrepresented in Chemistry at Northwestern University.  The project being performed by Dayna Patterson, entitled Characterization and biosynthesis of non-methanotrophic methanobactins, is to be conducted under the guidance of mentoring scientist Amy Rosenzweig. This project is supported by the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

Methane-oxidizing (methanotrophic) bacteria are known to acquire copper (Cu) for their function. To do so, many of the methanotrophic bacteria encode for ribosomally produced, post-translationally modified Cu-binding natural products known as methanobactins (Mbns).  Planned work is focused on elucidating the biosynthetic function of the uncharacterized biosynthetic protein, MbnX, which is involved in producing the still uncharacterized Group V Mbns.  The Fellow will utilize genetic, structural, and biochemical techniques to produce and characterize a new Mbn from the insect pathogen Xenorhabdus beddingii DSM 4764. The structure of this Mbn will provide insight into MbnX’s biosynthetic role, and to further understand MbnX, its structure and function will be explored.  Activities that will support broadening participation of underrepresented minorities in Chemistry will include a research shadowing experience for students from a local minority-serving community college, and starting a local chapter of the National Organization of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) which will nucleate a community for underrepresented students in STEM at Northwestern University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
My initial attempts to express MbnX in E. coli with and without an N-terminal solubility tag yielded insoluble aggregates. Since the MbnX N-terminal TIM barrel domain is a homolog of MbnB, I decided to express only the N-terminal TIM barrel domain of MbnX with a solubility tag, resulting in soluble protein. To obtain the TIM barrel domain by itself for Aim 3, protease cleavage reactions will be pursued and optimized. Although studying the MbnX TIM barrel domain will provide insight into its proposed iron binding site and reactivity with MbnA, knowledge of the full-length MbnX structure is required to understand the function of the C-terminal domain and its proposed recognition of MbnA. The Alphafold model of MbnX and MbnA predicts that the MbnA core region binds to a hydrophobic groove in the MbnX C-terminal domain. MbnA binding may result in a conformational change to bring the two domains together and stabilize the protein. With this hypothesis in mind, I linked the C-terminus of MbnX to the N-terminus of MbnA via a (Gly-Gly-Ser)3 linker and added a solubility tag to the N-terminus of MbnX. Remarkably, this construct has resulted in soluble protein and protease cleavage reactions to obtain protein for aim 3 are underway. 

The broader impact of this work have focused on outreach activities to introduce and mentor Chicago youth in STEM. I currently volunteer weekly as a Science Club mentor at the Boys and Girls Club Pederson-McCormick center in the Uptown neighborhood of Chicago. As a mentor, I guide Black and Latino middle-school students through a weekly science curriculum to explore hands-on projects and learn real-world science skills. In this position, I also have the opportunity to build genuine, strong relationships with students, boosting their science skills and instilling confidence through encouragement and regular support 

 


Last Modified: 04/22/2024
Modified by: Dayna C Patterson
